channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2012 The New York Times Company

item.title: Changing of the Guard: Chinese Opposition to Labor Camps Widens
item.description: Opponents of China’s “re-education through labor” system say new leadership could put an end to abuses at the labor camps, which confine perceived troublemakers without trial.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW JACOBS
item.media:description: Liu Jie, 60, said she was beaten and hogtied to a chair during the two years she was confined at a forced-labor camp.

item.title: Man Stabs 22 Children in China
item.description: A man wielding a knife wounded 22 children and one adult outside a primary school in the village of Chengping, as students were arriving for classes on Friday.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Changing of the Guard: China’s Communist Leader Acts to Bolster Military
item.description: Xi Jinping, the new party chief, casts strengthening the armed forces as a centerpiece of the “Chinese dream” of national rejuvenation.
item.dc:creator: By EDWARD WONG

item.title: After Fighting Markets, Europe Now Prefers Working With Them
item.description: An agreement on bank supervision is the latest attempt by the European Union to calm worries about banks, government finances and, by extension, its fundamental institutions.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW HIGGINS

item.title: A Political Pendulum in a Disgruntled Japan
item.description: Voters in Japan, disappointed in the Democratic Party’s failure to reverse the nation’s malaise, appear poised to hand power back to the old-guard Liberal Democrats.
item.dc:creator: By MARTIN FACKLER
item.media:credit: Ko Sasaki for The New York Times

item.title: With E.C.B. in Spotlight, Bundesbank Finds Itself in the Shadows
item.description: Just as the euro replaced the German mark, the European Central Bank has supplanted the Bundesbank as the continent’s pre-eminent economic institution.
item.dc:creator: By NICHOLAS KULISH
item.media:credit: Mustafah Abdulaziz for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Bundesbank, Germany’s central bank, built in 1967 in Frankfurt.

item.title: Panetta Orders Deployment of U.S. Antimissile Units in Turkey
item.description: Four hundred American military personnel and two Patriot air defense batteries will be sent from the United States as cross-border tensions intensify between Turkey and Syria.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By THOM SHANKER and MICHAEL R. GORDON
item.media:description: An injured woman was taken to a hospital in a rebel-controlled area of Aleppo on Friday.

item.title: Avigdor Lieberman, Israeli Foreign Minister, Resigns
item.description: Foreign Minister Avigdor Lieberman resigned on Friday after being charged with fraud and breach of trust, in a move that could have repercussions for next month’s elections.
item.dc:creator: By JODI RUDOREN
item.media:description: Avigdor Lieberman stood behind candles lit for the Jewish holiday of Hanukkah during a conference of his Yisrael Beiteinu party on Thursday in Tel Aviv.

item.title: D.J.’s in Prank Call Over Royals Forced Into Hiding
item.description: The two Australian D.J.’s who called a British hospital pretending to be Queen Elizabeth and Prince Charles have been taken off the air indefinitely.
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.dc:creator: By SARAH LYALL

item.title: Obama Walks a Fine Line With Egyptian President
item.description: As President Mohamed Morsi and his Muslim Brotherhood allies stood accused of authoritarianism, President Obama, via phone, urged him to offer his opposition compromises.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: Can You Be English if You Don't Speak English?
item.description: The leader of Britain's opposition Labour Party wants to ensure new immigrants learn English. His remarks are seen as a repositioning of policy on the issue of immigration. But do language skills matter that much in a multicultural society?
item.dc:creator: By HARVEY MORRIS
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: A market scene in London's multiethnic Brixton district.

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: Educating Students From Cultures That See Work as Exploitation
item.description: A new community college tackles the preconceptions of students from backgrounds where work is seen not as an outgrowth of one's passions, but as something negative or scarce.
item.dc:creator: By ANAND GIRIDHARADAS

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: An Online Plea to China's Leader to Save Tibet's Culture
item.description: Citing China's own Constitution, nearly 100 scholars at universities and institutes around the world, from Melbourne to Warsaw to Vancouver, are asking Xi Jinping to reverse policies and practices allegedly destroying the Tibetan language and culture.
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:description: Tibetan exiles protested in Dharamshala, India on Dec. 10. The rally marked the 64th anniversary of International Human Rights Day.

item.title: Russian Police Open New Case Against Aleksei Navalny
item.description: The activist and street protest leader, Aleksei A. Navalny, is already being questioned in two other cases and the new charges became public a day before a planned opposition rally.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW E. KRAMER

item.title: Syrian Rebel Seeks Prisoner Exchange to Free Hostages
item.description: Amar al-Dadikhi, commander of the North Storm brigade, said that he would free his hostages if the Syrian government released two prominent opposition figures and if Lebanon freed all Syrian activists in government custody.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By C. J. CHIVERS
item.media:description: Amar Dadikhi, the commander of one of many fighting groups seeking the overthrow of President Bashar al-Assad, is holding nine Lebanese hostages in Syria.

item.title: Egypt Prepares to Vote on Draft Constitution
item.description: Praying, protesting and waiting ahead of the country’s vote.

item.title: The Lede Blog: Journalists Punched by Israeli Officers After Fatal Shooting at West Bank Checkpoint
item.description: Two Palestinian journalists working for Reuters were punched by Israeli soldiers as they tried to reach the scene of a fatal shooting at a West Bank checkpoint this week.
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: German Lawmakers Seek to Ban Far-Right Party
item.description: The upper house of Parliament on Friday voted overwhelmingly to launch a new effort to have Germany's leading far-right political party deemed unconstitutional.
item.dc:creator: By MELISSA EDDY

item.title: The Lede Blog: Filmmakers Urge Egyptians to Reject Constitution
item.description: Activist filmmakers in Cairo have released a series of Web videos urging their fellow citizens to reject a new constitution hastily approved last month by Islamist allies of President Mohamed Morsi.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: Life Expectancy Rises Around World, Study Finds
item.description: More people worldwide are living into old age, but the gains in the United States were much smaller, according to a new study.
item.dc:creator: By SABRINA TAVERNISE
item.media:description: Children in Nairobi, Kenya. Sub-Saharan Africa lagged in mortality gains, compared with Latin America, Asia and North Africa.

item.title: Money Woes Could Erode High Hamas Standing in Gaza
item.description: Hamas has sought new support from Sunni governments like Qatar and the United Arab Emirates, but it has also raised taxes and fees considerably, prompting complaints from Gazans.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN ERLANGER
item.media:description: Gaza residents returned to survey the damage to their homes last month after a cease-fire ended the eight-day clash between Israel and Hamas.

item.title: Senate Panel Approves Findings on Prisoner Interrogations
item.description: The highly critical report on the C.I.A.’s detention and interrogation program is the most comprehensive review of the brutal treatment of Al Qaeda prisoners.
item.dc:creator: By SCOTT SHANE

item.title: Susan Rice’s Bluntness Endeared Her to President
item.description: Friends and former White House aides say that Susan E. Rice’s style is a reflection of President Obama’s: impatient with niceties, focused solely on results.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID E. SANGER and JODI KANTOR
item.media:description: Susan E. Rice before a cabinet meeting last month at which President Obama lauded the job she was doing. She will now, presumably, stay in her job.

item.title: Europe Court Finds Violation in C.I.A. Rendition
item.description: The European Court of Human Rights ruled that Macedonia violated the rights of Khaled el-Masri when it arrested him and turned him over to the United States.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By NICHOLAS KULISH
item.media:description: Khaled el-Masri during a court appearance in 2010.

item.title: Prosecutor Says Morsi Aides Interfered
item.description: The complaints raise the most serious questions yet about President Mohamed Morsi’s commitment to the rule of law and his ties to the Muslim Brotherhood.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK
item.media:credit: Tara Todras-Whitehill for The New York Times
item.media:description: A demonstrator in Cairo on Thursday tried to remove part of a wall near the palace where President Mohamed Morsi resides.
